But though he expressly disclaimed any wish to impose his own opinions on his contemporaries or successors (mail alri's praeeo quod sequantur), the authority oi his great name sufficed to induce a general suspension ofjudgement during the two centuries which succeeded his epoch. Some scholars adhered to the Tacitean tradition, others advocated Quintilian²z some took a new departure, ascribing the Dralogac to the younger Pliny, or to Suetonius, or to the poet-pleader who is its central figure, Curiatius Maternus.
